<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 119, 645, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 186]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 279, 208]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 170, 905, 230]]<|/det|>
9702/12 February/March 2025 1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 506, 262]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 278, 540, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 226, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 905, 504]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 533, 218, 546]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 570, 594]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 100, 668, 549]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{ms}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{ms}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\text{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\text{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\text{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{JK}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{Nm}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{mF}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{Js}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{Wm}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 585, 167, 600]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 612, 325, 840]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\) \(v^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\) hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\) upthrust \(F = \rho gV\) Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{v\pm v_{s}}\) electric current \(I = Anvq\) resistors in series \(R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\) resistors in parallel \(\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 70, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 70, 410, 88]]<|/det|>
Which quantity is a scalar quantity?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 100, 198, 115]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 106, 248, 120]]<|/det|>
force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 130, 250, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 126, 250, 141]]<|/det|>
momentum

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 154, 218, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 152, 218, 167]]<|/det|>
velocity

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 196, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 179, 196, 193]]<|/det|>
work

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 222, 96, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 799, 240]]<|/det|>
What is the effect of a systematic error on the measurement of a physical quantity?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 252, 141, 268]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 252, 517, 268]]<|/det|>
It limits the precision of the measured value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 278, 688, 294]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 275, 682, 293]]<|/det|>
It limits the range of values obtained in repeated measurements.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 780, 319]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 301, 780, 318]]<|/det|>
It results in repeated measurements having different values from each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 329, 724, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 328, 724, 345]]<|/det|>
It results in the measured value being different from the correct value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 374, 96, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 374, 667, 390]]<|/det|>
A car is accelerated by a constant resultant force of 300 N for 5.0 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 404, 672, 420]]<|/det|>
The variation with time of the velocity, in \(\text{cm s}^{- 1}\) , of the car is shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 432, 672, 606]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 622, 356, 638]]<|/det|>
What is the mass of the car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 735, 667]]<|/det|>
<pre>A 13kg B 1000kg C 1300kg D 10000kg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 696, 96, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 696, 920, 727]]<|/det|>
An aircraft, initially stationary on a runway, takes off with a speed of \(85 \text{kmh}^{-1}\) in a distance of no more than \(1.20 \text{km}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 742, 693, 757]]<|/det|>
What is the minimum constant acceleration necessary for the aircraft?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 769, 728, 785]]<|/det|>
<pre>A 0.23ms-2 B 0.46ms-2 C 3.0ms-2 D 6.0ms-2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
An object is fired upwards from horizontal ground. The object has an initial velocity of \(20 \text{m s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(45^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the speed of the object after it is fired until immediately before it reaches the ground again?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 161, 136, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 160, 777, 178]]<|/det|>
Its speed decreases to a value greater than zero, then increases to \(20 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 187, 138, 205]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 187, 918, 219]]<|/det|>
Its speed decreases to a value greater than zero, then increases to a value greater than \(20 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 228, 138, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 228, 608, 246]]<|/det|>
Its speed decreases to zero, then increases to \(20 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 255, 138, 273]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 255, 752, 272]]<|/det|>
Its speed decreases to zero, then increases to a value less than \(20 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 300, 96, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 300, 774, 317]]<|/det|>
What is a statement of the principle of conservation of momentum for a system?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 328, 744, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 327, 740, 345]]<|/det|>
The total momentum and the total kinetic energy are always conserved.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 354, 635, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 352, 635, 370]]<|/det|>
The total momentum is conserved only in elastic collisions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 732, 396]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 378, 732, 396]]<|/det|>
The total momentum is conserved provided that no external forces act.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 405, 876, 422]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 405, 876, 422]]<|/det|>
The total momentum of each object in the system is the product of its mass and velocity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 450, 96, 469]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 460, 467]]<|/det|>
Objects P and Q form an isolated system.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 480, 640, 497]]<|/det|>
Object P has mass \(6.0kg\) and is moving at a speed of \(3.0m s^{-1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
Object Q has mass \(2.0kg\) and is moving at a speed of \(4.2m s^{-1}\) at an angle of \(35^{\circ}\) to the path of P.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 553, 675, 672]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 688, 470, 705]]<|/det|>
Objects P and Q collide and stick together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 718, 920, 750]]<|/det|>
What is the magnitude of the component of the final momentum of the combined objects in the original direction of P?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 761, 744, 778]]<|/det|>
<pre>A \(9.6kgm s^{-1}\) B \(11kgm s^{-1}\) C \(13kgm s^{-1}\) D \(25kgm s^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
An astronaut of mass \(m\) in a spacecraft experiences a gravitational force \(F = mg\) when stationary on the launchpad.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 919, 150]]<|/det|>
What is the gravitational force on the astronaut when the spacecraft is launched vertically upwards with an acceleration of \(0.2g\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 160, 141, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 160, 208, 178]]<|/det|>
1.2mg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 160, 351, 178]]<|/det|>
B mg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 160, 542, 178]]<|/det|>
C 0.8mg

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 160, 666, 178]]<|/det|>
D 0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 206, 94, 224]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 919, 240]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a child X of mass \(20kg\) and a child Y of mass \(15kg\) seated on a uniform plank.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[274, 249, 718, 390]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 404, 919, 437]]<|/det|>
The plank has a mass of \(7.0kg\) and has a pivot at its midpoint. The plank is horizontal and in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 590, 467]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the weight of the plank is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 479, 141, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 479, 728, 496]]<|/det|>
The weight of the plank can be considered to be acting at its midpoint.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 505, 150, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 650, 522]]<|/det|>
The weight of the plank is causing an anticlockwise moment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 532, 160, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 610, 549]]<|/det|>
The weight of the plank is causing a clockwise moment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 558, 710, 575]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 558, 710, 575]]<|/det|>
The weight of the plank equals the force on the plank from the pivot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 602, 107, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 602, 440, 619]]<|/det|>
An object is fully submerged in a liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 630, 613, 664]]<|/det|>
A student determines the ratio \(\frac{\text{upthrust acting on the object}}{\text{weight of the object}}.\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 672, 591, 689]]<|/det|>
Which single change would double the value of this ratio?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 700, 141, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 700, 893, 717]]<|/det|>
Use a different liquid that has twice the density and the same volume as the original liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 727, 141, 745]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 727, 893, 744]]<|/det|>
Use a different object that has half the volume and the same density as the original object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 754, 141, 772]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 754, 903, 771]]<|/det|>
Use a different object that has twice the density and the same volume as the original object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 780, 140, 798]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 780, 903, 797]]<|/det|>
Use a different object that has twice the volume and the same density as the original object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 719, 90]]<|/det|>
A shop sign weighing \(75 \text{N}\) hangs from a frame attached to a vertical wall.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 101, 720, 306]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 320, 918, 368]]<|/det|>
The frame consists of a horizontal rod XY and a rod YZ that is at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. Rod XY is attached to the wall by a hinge at X and has length \(0.50 \text{m}\). Assume that the weights of the rods are negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 380, 600, 397]]<|/det|>
What is the horizontal force exerted by the wall on rod XY?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 409, 155, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 409, 183, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>0N</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 409, 360, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 409, 402, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>43N</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 409, 537, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[550, 409, 602, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>130N</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[663, 409, 703, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[715, 409, 753, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>150N</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 454, 107, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 754, 471]]<|/det|>
A student takes measurements to calculate the density of a liquid in a beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 485, 549, 502]]<|/det|>
The height of the liquid in the beaker is \(0.20 \text{m} \pm 2\%\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 516, 539, 533]]<|/det|>
The internal diameter of the beaker is \(0.05 \text{m} \pm 3\%\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 547, 444, 564]]<|/det|>
The mass of the liquid is \(0.36 \text{kg} \pm 10\%\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 578, 718, 594]]<|/det|>
What is the percentage uncertainty in the calculated density of the liquid?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 606, 143, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 606, 185, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>2%</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 606, 351, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 606, 400, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>5%</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 606, 527, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[540, 606, 693, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>15%</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 606, 693, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 606, 693, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>18%</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 720, 90]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a uniform plank XY of length 4.0 m and weight 300 N. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 101, 756, 235]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 248, 558, 265]]<|/det|> The plank rests on fixed supports at its ends X and Y. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 278, 648, 295]]<|/det|> A child of weight 600 N stands in different positions on the plank. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 308, 690, 325]]<|/det|> The support at end X exerts a force \(F\) vertically upwards on the plank. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 339, 830, 356]]<|/det|> What is the magnitude of \(F\) when the child stands at X and when the child stands at Y? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 368, 440, 513]]<|/det|>
\(F/N\) when child is at X\(F/N\) when child is at Y
A6000
B600150
C7500
D750150
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 540, 107, 558]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 540, 668, 558]]<|/det|> Which relationship is used in the derivation of the equation shown? <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 572, 600, 588]]<|/det|> \[\text{power} = \text{force} \times \text{velocity}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 603, 404, 619]]<|/det|> A displacement = velocity \(\times\) time <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 630, 384, 645]]<|/det|> B force = mass \(\times\) acceleration <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 658, 395, 673]]<|/det|> C momentum = mass \(\times\) velocity <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 685, 395, 700]]<|/det|> D velocity = acceleration \(\times\) time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
A block is released from rest at the top of a slope inclined at an angle to the horizontal. The slope has length \(L\) as shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 116, 633, 228]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 240, 519, 256]]<|/det|>
There are no resistive forces acting on the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 269, 592, 286]]<|/det|>
What is the speed of the block at the bottom of the slope?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 300, 740, 318]]<|/det|>
A \(4.43\sqrt{L\cos\theta}\) B \(4.43\sqrt{L\sin\theta}\) C \(19.6L\cos \theta\) D \(19.6L\sin \theta\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 350, 107, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 350, 918, 397]]<|/det|>
A skateboarder and her skateboard have a total mass of \(70\mathrm{kg}\) . She pushes on the ground with her foot to create a forward force \(F\) of \(25\mathrm{N}\) on herself and the skateboard, as shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[360, 406, 630, 580]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 594, 918, 626]]<|/det|>
The skateboarder and skateboard travel forwards a distance of \(0.50 \text{m}\) before the skateboarder lifts her foot from the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 640, 656, 656]]<|/det|>
What is the work done by \(F\) on the skateboarder and skateboard?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 668, 148, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 668, 196, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>13J</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 668, 358, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[381, 668, 533, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 668, 700, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>340J</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[613, 668, 700, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[700, 668, 750, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>360J</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 714, 107, 731]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 714, 920, 761]]<|/det|>
A turbine at a hydroelectric power station is situated at a vertical distance of \(30 \text{m}\) below the level of the surface of a large lake. The water passes through the turbine at a rate of \(340 \text{m}^3\) per minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 775, 918, 807]]<|/det|>
The overall efficiency of the turbine and generator system is \(90\%\) . The density of water is \(1000 \text{kg} \text{m}^{-3}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 820, 555, 836]]<|/det|>
What is the useful power output of the power station?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 847, 714, 863]]<|/det|>
<pre>A 0.15MW B 1.5MW C 1.7MW D 90MW

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 728, 90]]<|/det|>
A projectile is launched at \(45^{\circ}\) to the horizontal with initial kinetic energy \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
Assuming air resistance to be negligible, what will be the kinetic energy of the projectile when it reaches its highest point?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 145, 670, 163]]<|/det|>
A \(0.50E\) B \(0.71E\) C \(0.87E\) D \(E\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 191, 107, 209]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 191, 684, 208]]<|/det|>
A wire is extended by a tensile force so that its deformation is elastic.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 221, 435, 238]]<|/det|>
What is meant by elastic deformation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 250, 141, 267]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 250, 644, 267]]<|/det|>
The extension of the wire is proportional to the tensile force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 277, 678, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 273, 678, 291]]<|/det|>
The extension of the wire is **not** proportional to the tensile force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 811, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 300, 812, 317]]<|/det|>
When the tensile force is removed, the wire does **not** return to its original length.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 742, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 327, 742, 344]]<|/det|>
When the tensile force is removed, the wire returns to its original length.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 373, 107, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 504, 390]]<|/det|>
A bolt is subjected to a tensile force, as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 533, 890, 550]]<|/det|>
The bolt has a circular cross-section. At end X, the diameter is \(2d.\) At end Y, the diameter is \(d.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 570, 366, 597]]<|/det|>
What is the ratio \(\frac{\text{stress at Y}}{\text{stress at X}}?\)

0.25

The axis of each spring is in a vertical direction. These four springs support a total load of 160 N. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 530, 667, 548]]<|/det|> What is the total elastic potential energy stored in the four springs? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 558, 707, 576]]<|/det|> **A** 0.048 J **B** 0.19 J **C** 0.38 J **D** 0.77 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 604, 107, 622]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 604, 725, 622]]<|/det|> Which row correctly identifies the properties of all electromagnetic waves? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 634, 520, 777]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 792, 90]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 300, 117]]<|/det|>
A \(100\mathrm{nm}\) to \(400\mathrm{nm}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 289, 144]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 154, 300, 170]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 312, 196]]<|/det|>
D \(800\mathrm{nm}\) to \(1000\mu \mathrm{m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 225, 107, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 918, 258]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a car travelling at a constant speed in a straight line between person P and person Q from point X to point Y.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 268, 845, 373]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 384, 897, 401]]<|/det|>
The car sounds its horn continuously as it travels. The horn emits sound of constant frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 415, 918, 448]]<|/det|>
Which statements about what person P and person Q hear during the motion of the car are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 460, 626, 477]]<|/det|>
1 Person P hears a sound of increasing frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 486, 635, 503]]<|/det|>
2 Person Q hears a sound of decreasing frequency.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 513, 777, 529]]<|/det|>
3 Person Q always hears a sound of higher frequency than person P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 542, 141, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 542, 240, 559]]<|/det|>
1, 2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 568, 257, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 568, 257, 585]]<|/det|>
1 and 2 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 207, 611]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 594, 207, 610]]<|/det|>
3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 621, 264, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 619, 264, 636]]<|/det|>
none of them

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 664, 107, 683]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 664, 762, 681]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 694, 918, 711]]<|/det|>
What is the phase difference between two points on the wave that are a distance of \(0.50 \text{m}\) apart?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 721, 136, 740]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 721, 185, 740]]<|/det|>
45°

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 721, 351, 740]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 721, 528, 740]]<|/det|>
C 180°

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 721, 695, 740]]<|/det|>
D 360°

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 780, 90]]<|/det|> A polarised beam of light with intensity \(I\) is incident normally on a polarising filter. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 104, 413, 120]]<|/det|> The transmitted light has intensity \(I\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 135, 619, 151]]<|/det|> The filter is rotated about the normal axis through an angle \(\theta\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 166, 450, 182]]<|/det|> The transmitted light has intensity \(0.75I\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 197, 292, 213]]<|/det|> What is the angle \(\theta\)? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 685, 241]]<|/det|> A \(30^{\circ}\) B \(42^{\circ}\) C \(49^{\circ}\) D \(60^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 271, 107, 288]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 271, 465, 287]]<|/det|> Light waves are emitted from two sources. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 790, 317]]<|/det|> What is a necessary condition for observable interference fringes to be produced? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 400, 345]]<|/det|> A The waves must be polarised. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 355, 435, 370]]<|/det|> B The waves must **not** be polarised. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 398, 396]]<|/det|> C The waves must be coherent. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 407, 485, 422]]<|/det|> D The waves must have equal amplitudes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 451, 107, 470]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 451, 919, 482]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a water wave in a shallow tank. The wave is diffracted through a gap in a barrier and spreads. The wavelength of the wave is much smaller than the width of the gap. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 492, 574, 613]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 626, 861, 643]]<|/det|> The wavelength of the wave and the width of the gap are both changed by a small amount. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 656, 853, 672]]<|/det|> Which combination of changes **must** increase the amount of spreading due to diffraction? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 686, 448, 813]]<|/det|>
wavelengthwidth of gap
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesincreases
Cincreasesdecreases
Dincreasesincreases

The grating has 400 lines per mm. A number of diffraction maxima are observed on the far side of the grating. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 821, 135]]<|/det|> What is the angle between the second-order maximum and the third-order maximum? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 146, 150, 164]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 146, 200, 164]]<|/det|> 13.1° <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 146, 370, 164]]<|/det|> B \(13.9^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 146, 540, 164]]<|/det|> C \(15.9^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 146, 700, 164]]<|/det|> D \(27.0^{\circ}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 191, 107, 210]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 191, 919, 223]]<|/det|> Two cylindrical conductors, X and Y, are made from the same material. The conductors have equal lengths, but Y has a smaller diameter than X. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 236, 456, 253]]<|/det|> X and Y are connected in series to a cell. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 266, 919, 298]]<|/det|> Which row compares the number of charge carriers per unit time passing through X and through Y and compares the average drift speed of the charge carriers in X and in Y? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 311, 581, 456]]<|/det|>
number of charge carriers per unit timeaverage drift speed of charge carriers
AY greater than XY greater than X
BY same as XY same as X

DY same as XY greater than X
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 484, 107, 503]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 484, 599, 502]]<|/det|> A copper wire is \(6.4 \text{m}\) long and has a resistance of \(0.92 \Omega\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 515, 459, 532]]<|/det|> The resistivity of copper is \(1.8 \times 10^{-8} \Omega \text{m}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 545, 390, 562]]<|/det|> What is the diameter of the wire? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 575, 755, 592]]<|/det|> A \(5.7 \times 10^{-5} \text{m}\) B \(1.0 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}\) C \(4.0 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}\) D \(7.1 \times 10^{-4} \text{m}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 678, 90]]<|/det|>
A thermistor is connected to a cell with negligible internal resistance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 102, 577, 192]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 870, 223]]<|/det|>
Which graph shows the variation with temperature of power, \(P\), dissipated in the thermistor?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[233, 234, 760, 555]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 586, 107, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 586, 918, 619]]<|/det|>
A metal electrical conductor has a resistance of \(5.6 \text{k}\Omega\). A potential difference (p.d.) of \(9.0 \text{V}\) is applied across its ends.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 632, 656, 649]]<|/det|>
How many electrons pass a point in the conductor in one minute?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 660, 737, 679]]<|/det|>
A \(6.0 \times 10^{20}\) B \(1.0 \times 10^{19}\) C \(6.0 \times 10^{17}\) D \(1.0 \times 10^{16}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 707, 107, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 707, 918, 739]]<|/det|>
Which circuit symbol does **not** represent an electric component that is designed to emit sound waves?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 750, 777, 820]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a junction in a circuit where three wires, P, Q and R, meet. The currents in P and Q are 1A and 3A respectively, in the directions shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 115, 690, 248]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 263, 653, 281]]<|/det|>
How much charge passes a given point in wire R in a time of 5s?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 292, 693, 310]]<|/det|>
A 0.4C B 2C C 10C D 20C

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 338, 107, 356]]<|/det|>
<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 338, 918, 370]]<|/det|>
A cell of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E\) and internal resistance \(r\) is connected in series with a switch S and an external resistor of resistance \(R\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 380, 630, 515]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 529, 551, 547]]<|/det|>
The potential difference (p.d.) between P and Q is V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 677, 577]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct when S is changed from open to closed?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 588, 129, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 588, 528, 606]]<|/det|>
V increases because there is a p.d. across \(R\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 129, 634]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 616, 528, 634]]<|/det|>
V decreases because there is a p.d. across \(r\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 644, 918, 676]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label> V remains the same because the decrease of p.d. across \(r\) is balanced by the increase of p.d. across \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 682, 133, 700]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 682, 832, 700]]<|/det|>
V remains the same because the sum of the p.d.s across \(r\) and \(R\) is still equal to \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 727, 107, 745]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 727, 467, 745]]<|/det|>
What is a general description of a baryon?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 756, 148, 774]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 756, 648, 774]]<|/det|>
It consists of three quarks that must all be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 784, 700, 801]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 783, 700, 800]]<|/det|>
It consists of three quarks that do **not** need to be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 810, 650, 827]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 809, 650, 826]]<|/det|>
It consists of two quarks that **must** both be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 836, 138, 854]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 836, 687, 853]]<|/det|>
It consists of two quarks that do **not** need to be the same flavour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 480, 88]]<|/det|>
A stationary nucleus has nucleon number \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 918, 134]]<|/det|>
The nucleus decays by emitting a proton with speed \(v\) to form a new nucleus with speed \(u\). The new nucleus and the proton move away from one another in opposite directions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 147, 480, 163]]<|/det|>
Which equation gives \(v\) in terms of \(A\) and \(u\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 173, 260, 273]]<|/det|>
A \(v = (\frac{A}{4} - 1)u\) B \(v = (A - 1)u\) C \(v = Au\) D \(v = (A + 1)u\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 301, 107, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 301, 868, 318]]<|/det|>
What is the change to the quark composition of a nucleus that takes place during \(\beta^{+}\) decay?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 277, 425]]<|/det|>
A down to antiup B down to up C up to antidown D up to down

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 452, 107, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 452, 740, 469]]<|/det|>
What is the charge, in terms of the elementary charge \(e\) , on a charm quark?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 484, 700, 514]]<|/det|>
A \(-\frac{2}{3} e\) B \(-\frac{1}{3} e\) C \(+\frac{1}{3} e\) D \(+\frac{2}{3} e\)
